summary: This is a petition filed in the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands to probate the estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein following his death. It includes the will, asset inventory, and appointments of Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn as executors. The document reveals the substantial value of Epstein's estate and his declared domicile in the U.S. Virgin Islands. This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, executed on August 8, 2019, in New York, New York. It outlines the extensive powers granted to his executor(s) to manage his estate, including investment, business, and legal authority, and contains standard will provisions regarding taxes, contests, and distribution.

locations: Little St. James Island, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's estate was valued at approximately $577.6 million at the time of his death, including cash, investments, real estate, and other assets.
Epstein's last will, dated August 8, 2019—two days before his death—directs all his assets into a trust called The 1953 Trust.
Epstein declared his domicile as St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands, at the time of his death, which is the jurisdiction for probate.
Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and sole heir, entitled to 100% of the estate if there were no will.
The death certificate lists the cause of death as 'Pending Further Study' and notes the place of death as the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.
Jeffrey Epstein's will was signed on August 8, 2019, shortly before his death in jail on August 10, 2019.
The will grants extraordinarily broad powers to the executor(s), including the authority to manage complex investments, continue business operations, and handle environmental liabilities.
It contains a 'no-contest' clause designed to disinherit any beneficiary who challenges the will's validity.
The document references a separate 'Trust Agreement' which is incorporated by reference and is intended to receive the bulk of the estate.
The will was witnessed and notarized, with Wilma A. Coto Vail identified as a Notary Public.
